title: 114_s2182
content:
The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" establishes spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House of Representatives and the Senate to prevent exceeding set budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made by the Committee on the Budget for enforcement purposes. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House and Senate to prevent exceeding budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made by the Committee on the Budget for enforcement purposes, including allocations and suballocations. If appropriations for fiscal year 2016 designate amounts for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism, allowable adjustments shall not exceed $58 billion in budget authority and outlays. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" establishes spending limits for fiscal year 2016 in the House and Senate to prevent exceeding budget authority and outlays. It includes exemptions for certain functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. Additionally, the Act enforces discretionary and direct spending caps through sequestration. The sequesters will be implemented for discretionary and direct spending limits separately. Direct spending sequestration will be enforced according to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain payments are exempt from sequestration. Presidential order may be modified. The sequesters for discretionary and direct spending limits will be implemented separately. Certain payments like TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations are exempt. Presidential order can be modified after the Director of the Office of Management and Budget issues a sequestration report. The joint resolution would enforce reductions in new budget authority and outlays for the fiscal year, with a point of order against any bill or resolution that alters a sequestration order without achieving the same level of reductions. TITLE II--CAP

SEC. 201. LIMIT ON TOTAL SPENDING.

Definitions amended to include GDP as gross domestic product for fiscal year. Caps enforced on GDP outlay limits. The section enforces GDP outlay limits based on projected GDP for fiscal years 2016 to 2025. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget determines the GDP outlay limit for each budget year, including all federal outlays. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes the GDP outlay limit for the budget year, including all federal outlays. Sequestration to enforce this section will be implemented as per the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain programs are exempt from this section. SEC. 320 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 prohibits considering any legislation that would exceed the current GDP outlay limits. This enforcement procedure aims to maintain fiscal responsibility in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 301 of TITLE III requires a balanced budget amendment to be submitted to the States, with provisions including limiting total outlays to not exceed total receipts, setting a spending limitation as a percentage of GDP, and requiring tax increases to be approved by a \2/3\ vote in both Houses of Congress for ratification. It also prohibits any legislation causing additional borrowing authority until the balanced budget amendment is transmitted to the States.
